content: The Act may be cited as the "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Act, known as the "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017," provides definitions for key terms such as Administration, Administrator, air carrier, and appropriate congressional committees. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms such as "foreign air carrier," "intelligence community," and "secured area" in relation to aviation security. The curr_chunk defines terms related to aviation security such as "secured area," "security identification display area," and "sterile area." The curr_chunk focuses on the cost and feasibility study related to aviation security. The Administrator, in consultation with the Aviation Security Advisory Committee, must submit a cost and feasibility study on airport security to congressional committees and the Comptroller General within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The study will assess the impact of implementing secure doors with card and pin entry or biometric technology at various airports. The study required under subsection (a) will assess airport security measures including secure doors with card and pin entry or biometric technology, surveillance video recording, and advanced screening technologies like magnetometers, explosives detection canines, and X-ray bag screening technology. The study will include information on employee screening costs at airports that screen 100% of employees accessing secured areas, including costs of entry and exit points and comparing costs and effectiveness of security features. The study will compare estimated costs and effectiveness of security features for the Federal Government and airports/aviation community. The Comptroller General will assess the quality and reliability of the study within 60 days of receiving it. The Comptroller General will assess the quality and reliability of a study on security features for the Federal Government and airports/aviation community within 60 days of receiving it. SEC. 4. AIRPORT WORKER EDUCATION AND SECURITY AWARENESS. The Administrator will collaborate with various stakeholders to enhance security awareness among airport workers regarding insider threats and best practices for access controls. Additionally, credentialing standards will be established in consultation with air carriers, foreign air carriers, and airport operators. The Administrator will assess credentialing standards with stakeholders to address insider threats to aviation security. A report on the assessment results will be submitted to congressional committees within 30 days. The Administrator will require airport operators to submit social security numbers for individuals applying for access to the Security Identification Display Area to enhance security vetting. Failure to provide a social security number may result in denial of the credential. The Administrator will require airport operators to include a notice in applications for access to a Security Identification Display Area, informing applicants that screening may occur at any time. Failure to provide a social security number may lead to denial of the credential. SEC. 5. SECURING AIRPORT WORKER ACCESS. The Administrator will collaborate with airport operators and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee to identify advanced technologies, including biometric identification, for securing employee access to airport secured and sterile areas. Additionally, within 180 days of the Act's enactment, all credentialed aviation workers requiring fingerprint-based criminal record checks will be continuously vetted through the FBI's Rap Back Service to swiftly detect and address insider threats to aviation security. The Administrator will enhance the Administration's ability to educate personnel on insider threats to aviation security and mitigate such threats. Additionally, employee physical inspection efforts of aviation will be led by the Administration. The Administrator will conduct covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness and provide results to airport operators. The Administrator will provide testing results and recommendations to airport operators, air carriers, and foreign air carriers. Additionally, they will submit annual reports for fiscal years 2018 through 2022. The Administrator will establish a national database of individuals with revoked airport badges within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Annual reports on employee inspection operations at airports will be submitted for fiscal years 2018 through 2022. The legislation requires the establishment of a national database for individuals with revoked airport badges, along with reporting mechanisms for airlines and airport operators to submit and access data. Additionally, a process will be set up for individuals mistakenly entered into the database to correct their information. The legislation mandates a national database for individuals with revoked airport badges and a process for correcting mistaken entries. The Department of Homeland Security leads insider threat coordination efforts at airports, working with other government entities, air carriers, foreign carriers, and airport operators. Additionally, there are provisions for information technology security. The Administrator must submit a plan for recurring reviews of security controls for airport IT systems within 90 days of this Act. No extra funds are authorized for these requirements. The House of Representatives passed the bill on April 25, 2017. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
